title: The Scroll of Print
subtitle: Your First Spell
description:
# Welcome to Godot Quest!

You've discovered an ancient scroll that contains the most fundamental spell in all of game programming: **the print spell**.

This spell allows you to display messages to the console - a magical window where your code speaks to you during game development.

## The Print Spell

In GDScript (Godot's language), the print spell looks like this:

```gdscript
print("Hello, game developer!")
```

**How it works:**
- `print` is the spell name
- The parentheses `()` hold the message you want to display
- The quotation marks `""` tell GDScript this is text (called a **String**)

## Your Quest

Cast the print spell to display the message:

**Welcome to Godot Quest!**

Then, on a new line, cast another print spell to display:

**I am ready to make games!**
starterCode:
# Cast your print spells here
# Remember: print("your message")
solutionCode:
# Cast your print spells here
print("Welcome to Godot Quest!")
print("I am ready to make games!")
hints: Use the print() function twice - once for each message
Don't forget the quotation marks around your text: print("like this")
Make sure each print statement is on its own line
Check your spelling - 'print' is all lowercase
Copy the exact messages: 'Welcome to Godot Quest!' and 'I am ready to make games!'

validationTests.description: Output should contain 'Welcome to Godot Quest!'

validationTests.value: I am ready to make games!
validationTests.description: Output should contain 'I am ready to make games!'

learningObjectives: Understand what the print() function does in Godot
Learn to use quotation marks for Strings
See immediate output from your code
Write your first working GDScript program
